|  | Mod Periods | Periods we use in forecasting |  |
|  | Historical Mod Data | Which mods, which shelves had which products |  |
|  | Store-Product Availability Data | Determines the product scope of the problem for each store |  |
|  | Innovation Item List | List of items that has no historical presence |  |
|  | Reference Item List | New items and items that has representative sales for the new items |  |
|  | Product Size Details | Detailed info in G:\Team Drives\Pepsi\MasterTables2\Store Capacity and Item Location Notes.docx |  |
|  | Modular Size & Capacity Details | Store-Category based shelf width and depth info |  |
|  | Neverout Item List | Store-Product based neverout item list which also includes max-min cap info |  |

everout Item List | Store-Product based neverout item list which also includes max-min cap info |  |
|  | Store-Product-Category | Predetermined category assignments of products |  |
|  | Substitution Table | Substitution probabilities between each pair of items |  |
|  | Product Value | Average sale prices(ASP) of the items |  |
|  | Product Cluster | Velocity clusters for products |  |
|  | Cluster Level | Representative velocities of the velocity clusters |  |
|  | Store SL | Store service-levels |  |
|  | Store Forecast Multiplier | Manually determined forecast multipliers for each store since we overshoot or undershoot in these stores |  |
|  | Max-Min Cap | Maximum or minimum allowed capacities for stores. Minimum capacity rule is valid only if capacity>0. |  |
|  | Parameter for Standard Deviation Calculation |  |  |
|  | Store-Product Cluster | Velocity Clusters for Store and Product |  |
|  | Coke Forecast | Week-end day forecast values by Coke |  |

Paper 1Title of the Paper:A Demand Estimation Procedure for Retail Assortment Optimization with Results from Implementations

Authors:Marshall Fisher, Ramnath Vaidyanathan

Purpose:To give a binary decision for each available product(whether to put the item or not). Number of facings, capacity etc. are not considered in the paper.

1. Each item has features and each feature has levels(e.g., a feature is flavor and a level of this feature is "Cheese").
2. Substitution probabilities between levels of any feature are defined.Substitution probabilities between items are products of substitution probabilities between levels of each feature of the items.

etween items are products of substitution probabilities between levels of each feature of the items.
3. The probability that a customer purchases an item is defined as base sale probability plus the sales corresponding to sales by substitution to the item from another item that is not in the assortment.The probability that a customer purchases any item is defined as sum of these probabilities.Likelihood function is defined using these definitions and the historical-sales data.Parameters(substitution probabilities between levels of each feature, and base sale probabilities of items) are estimated using a sample path gradient algorithm. Specifics of the algorithm is not clear in the paper.Sample path gradient algorithms are defined vaguely in the paper as numerical optimization(probably gradient descent) algorithms using several randomly generated starting points; this makes it more probable that the algorithm reaches a global optimum rather than getting stuck at a local optimum.

e probable that the algorithm reaches a global optimum rather than getting stuck at a local optimum.
4. Once the parameters are found, we have the reward function to be maximized. Then, greedy and interchange heuristics are used to maximize the reward.

Elements of the paper that did not work in the project and suggestions to make them work:

1. The optimization problem of finding the parameters that maximizes the likelihood function has too many parameters for a numerical optimization algorithm to find plausible results.Although we tried to find the parameters using the methods suggested in the paper, the results were implausible. For example: the algorithm assigned a high probability to substitution from a Lays Classic Multipack to a small Cheetos BBQ.

hm assigned a high probability to substitution from a Lays Classic Multipack to a small Cheetos BBQ.

Suggestions to make it work and the justification: Based on our learning throughout the project, we know that substitution probabilities, especially those between products that have low demands, have little effect on the assortment decisions. Therefore, it is plausible to only focus on the most important substitutions. In this context, the most important substitutions would be those that has the highest impact on the sales. This way, the number of parameters could be significantly smaller and numerical optimization algorithms would yield better results.

Paper 2

We did not employ any method from this paper since we thought that it was practical to start with simpler models.

Title of the Paper:Shelf-Space Management under Stockout-Based Substitution and Merchandising Constraints

Authors:Dmitry Smirnov, Arnd Huchzermeier

Purpose:

ased Substitution and Merchandising Constraints

Authors:Dmitry Smirnov, Arnd Huchzermeier

Purpose:

1. To design an optimal shelf layout, which includes the decision regarding the vertical position of the product and number of facings. Horizontal position is not considered.
2. To estimate the demand taking into account the space elasticity and the cross-space elasticity of the products.

Parameters for Purpose 1:

1. Length, height, and width of the products and the shelves
2. Maximum allowed number of stacks for a product

Decision Variables for Purpose 1:

1. The shelf level of the products
2. The number of facings of the products

Parameters for Purpose 2:

1. Number of facings, shelf level of a products
2. Base market share of the products(excluding any effect of the other products in the assortment)

Decision Variables for Purpose 2:

1. Effect of the shelf level of the products
2. Effect of the allocated shelf space of the products

1. Effect of the shelf level of the products
2. Effect of the allocated shelf space of the products

### Ceiling Analysis

Objective:It will show to maximum benefit of the assortment decision. If we put every item in every store, what is our expected revenue in 100% in-stock rate?Methodology:Create all possible distinct store-product combination. Calculate forecast for the pairs which don't have historical sales. Compare this results with the observed results. This analyses can be done by using substitution matrix and with zero substitution assumption.Sample Project ResultsSample Code

### ADI Analysis

Objective:

- Evaluate "ADI" (Attribute Development Indices):
- Develop store-level development index for each attribute & constrain or compare each store’s assortment in that dimension to the average level of the index in similar stores.
- This will help automate and control questions such as “do we a sufficient mix of XYZ flavor or 12-packs in this particular store?

2. Can the parameters of the model be estimated well?Is the number of parameters small enough to allow for a plausible numerical method(a gradient descent algo) to estimate the parameters well?Lower the number of parameters(substitution) to make the estimation well.Run the gradient descent algorithm smartly(For using the method in Fischer paper): Plot Cost versus Time: Collect and plot the cost values calculated by the algorithm each iteration. The expectation for a well performing gradient descent run is a decrease in cost each iteration. If it does not decrease, try reducing your learning rate.Learning Rate: The learning rate value is a small real value such as 0.1, 0.001 or 0.0001. Try different values for your problem and see which works best.Rescale Inputs: The algorithm will reach the minimum cost faster if the shape of the cost function is not skewed and distorted

thm will reach the minimum cost faster if the shape of the cost function is not skewed and distorted. You can achieved this by rescaling all of the input variables (X) to the same range, such as [0, 1] or [-1, 1].Few Passes: Stochastic gradient descent often does not need more than 1-to-10 passes through the training dataset to converge on good or good enough coefficients.Plot Mean Cost: The updates for each training dataset instance can result in a noisy plot of cost over time when using stochastic gradient descent. Taking the average over 10, 100, or 1000 updates can give you a better idea of the learning trend for the algorithm.

1. Products that are brought to a store in the same truck are on the same category(85 or 185) in the store.
2. If there exists a under-shelf rack, then the height of the shelf under it will be shorter. Current solution does not deal with it.
3. We do not make decision for the assortment of next-gen items. Pepsi allocates a certain amount of space in the shelf for these items. The specialty solution data is G:\Team Drives\Pepsi\InventData\MasterTablesV2\SpecialtyData.csv.If the specialty solution is Gondola, total linear footage will decrease by 4 feet for all shelves.If a store has Warehouse On Shelf Rack Flag then we will decrease store linear inch by 70 inch. It will be only effective for second shelf.
4. The brand that is the store leader takes the action alley in the store.

fective for second shelf.
4. The brand that is the store leader takes the action alley in the store.
5. There exist children items and parent items. If a child item is in the assortment, then the parent item should also be in the assortment.The data is in the MasterTablesV2 folder and named "Child_ParentRelation_CSD.csv".
6. 6-10 pack rule(For Mini Cans).For Coke Products: If 10 pack item is available it gets priority, there will be no 6 pack mini can on mod.For DPSG Products: If 10 pack item is available it gets priority, there will be no 6/8 packs mini can on mod.For Pepsi Products: 15 pack mini cans will be in all stores and will be incremental to the 6pk. 7. Sales with promotion in forecasting.We did not include special days in our forecasting.Another point somewhat related to promotion is, we detected off-mod support from comparing the mod data with the sales data. If the sales of an item is significantly higher than what the mod has, we concluded that there must be off-mod support for the item. However exact data on off-mod support would be very helpful.This is also related to off-mod support. Note that the assortment decisions are immutable within a period. Therefore, standard deviation of sales of a product is significantly affected by promotions(or change in the price of the product); it is better if we could differentiate between standard deviations corresponding to distinct periods of different prices.When a product is in promotion, we should be able to take into account the possible stockout of the product and whether the product will get off-mod support.

into account the possible stockout of the product and whether the product will get off-mod support.
8. We utilize substitution data from WM. This data includes 5 substitute items for each main item, and a substitution score attributed to the substitute item, which quantifies the willingness of a customer to substitute to the item given that the main item is not in the assortment.WM calculates this using the info of a customer's purchases at different times. If the customer purchases an item and next time, the item is not in the assortment, the purchases the customer makes the next time are considered as substitute items. The following is an explanation we did not confirm but seems plausible: Aggregating the purchase info of many customers, they hope to find which purchases are really substitute items and which purchases are independent of the previous purchases.
9. We have a minimum facing constraint for the warehouse items.

dependent of the previous purchases.
9. We have a minimum facing constraint for the warehouse items.
10. Expected sales function is not working properly; it yields inaccurate values for, roughly speaking, inputs in the tails of the sales distribution. Because of this, we correct the expected sales values: With the current expected sales function, there are some Store-Product pairs for which the expected sales value decreases(very slightly) when the capacity increases. For these pairs, we find the smallest capacity value at which the expected sales tends to remain the same as the capacity increases. Then, we artificially increase the expected sales values for the larger capacity values.

1. The algorithm only uses the most efficient orientation of a product.  Efficiency can be better calculated by using the ExpectedSales function.Probably, the reason why our first approach was yielding questionable results is that we were using service level to calculate the efficiency instead of using the expected sales function. Note that the service-level calculation(ServiceLevel*Average Sales) was inaccurate.Both of the orientations of the products can be considered via an exchange algorithm after the initial assortment decisions are made. If changing the orientation increases the sales, keep it; however, while doing this, shelf usage should be tracked and overuse or underuse of shelf capacity should be avoided.

ing this, shelf usage should be tracked and overuse or underuse of shelf capacity should be avoided.
2. If the store is sufficiently big and there are sufficiently many items for each of the items in the store, then the decision of which product to put next is based on DOS, not the ExpectedSales function.One reason for this is that the ExpectedSales function is not perfectly accurate. Another reason might be that because the demand distribution, on the contrary to our assumptions, might not be normally distributed, our expected sales calculation might be becoming increasingly inaccurate in the tails of the distribution. Extreme value theory could be used to adjust the unrealistically thick tails of the normal distribution.

We should also create a sales deck that will help us market the AO product. We can utilize Karabulut for his guidance in this area.

It would also be nice to have internal FAQ for onboarding new members to this tool. FAQ can also include subtle points where clients are more concerned.

We can also have list of potential customers.

Goal:To cluster the stores using the ADI scores of them.

Method:

1. Determine the most important features.Features that best explain the sales.Features that best explain the substitution.
2. Perform k-means clustering using ADI scores of important features to create 40 clusters.Example: The ADI score of a trademark(say Pepsi) to be used in clustering is calculated by; (1) Find the proportion of sales belonging to the products of Pepsi, (2) Normalize the ADI scores for each trademark by subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation.Run k-means clustering via these ADI scores. We manually determined coefficients for features that reflect the importance of the features.
3. Decrease the number of clusters using manual investigation.Utilize average ADI scores of the clusters and information regarding ethnic and economic status of the customers belonging to the clusters to combine them into larger groups of clusters.

| Table ID | Table Name | Table Explanation | Must Have? (1=YES, 0=NO) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | Product Universe | Determines the scope of the assortment optimization | 1 |
|  | Store Universe | Determines the stores which the opt. system will run for | 1 |
|  | Product Table | Involves necessary attributes and info related to produccts | 1 |
|  | Store Shipment Freq and SL | Target calculation part of the assortment opt. tool is capable of taking the shipment frequency and service level in store level. (Default values can be used as well) | 0 |
|  | Pair Based ServiceLevel | In order to rule service level pair based. | 0 |
|  | MinMax Capacity | Takes the additional constraints related to assortment selections and selected store's capacity planning | 0 |
|  | Item Shelf Relation | Includes constraints related to item-shelf match | 1 |
|  | Substitution | Includes the substitution values in between the products | 0 |

shelf match | 1 |
|  | Substitution | Includes the substitution values in between the products | 0 |
|  | New Item (Proxy) Forecast Factor | Reference Item & Similarity % for new products | 1 |
|  | Store Size | Stores shelf sizes (depth&length) | 1 |
|  | Forecast | Product - Store Weekend day forecast & Standard deviation values | 1 |
|  | SWAP | Holds the product code altered items information | 0 |

### Input Data

Depth Decision: Although initial plan was to divide shelf length to product depth and calculate capacity per facing (num in facing) accordingly,

since we observe some differences in Pepsi Initial Result - Invent comparison;

NumInFacing = Pepsi Capacity / Pepsi Facing is calculated.

Flexible Pack / Calculated Width Issue:

Except cartoon cube products' products are able to be compressed so that's why there is also another calculated product width.

This calculated width takes the compression ability into consideration as well.

Product Size Info Table:

ProductCode - Height - Width - Depth - CalculatedProductWidth

Target Input:

In order not to calculate target in the code (and decrease the process time) the targets which are calculated earlier are being used as input:

### Special Rules and Constraints:

i) Off Mod Issue

ii) Single Facing Issue

iii) Dips Configuration

iv) Cubic Item Approach

v) Shelf Length Configuration

### Constraints

i) Hard Constraints:

metadata.title: Special to Pepsi - Documentation Notes - SALTY

content:
ation

iv) Cubic Item Approach

v) Shelf Length Configuration

### Constraints

i) Hard Constraints:

-Availability file

-Product shelf assignment (6 shelf only products, MP only products etc.)

-Store total footage

-Four foot incremental/two foot incremental rule based on store total footage

ii) Heuristics:

-DOS limit (1.2 for HV stores 2 for others)

-One facing percentage (overall average should be around 8-10%)

Invent Mode Constraint Usage

Invent system directly uses the hard constraints.  Current heuristics are not using in the model as we have integrate expected sales as a function of:

-Service level

-Pair expected variance

-Shipment frequency

Above parameters address objectives of current heuristics

We mainly use them as a reference point/guideline

For each cube product, the tool gives even number of facing to make them stacked.

metadata.title: Special to Pepsi - Documentation Notes - SALTY

content:
e point/guideline

For each cube product, the tool gives even number of facing to make them stacked.

For the top shelve items, we have to give minimum two facing because they need to be stacked. We also need to create an even number of facing for those.

For the products in 6 shelve, same trademarks should be on under the other (Color constraint). *We don't have an existing systematic solution for this constraint.*

### Existing Pepsi Assortment Planning Approach:

i) Group mod & Store specific mod logic & Methodology

Several templates exists and assortment planning is made for these templates.

Some template examples:

4 feet Shelf-6 + 8 feet Shelf-7 + 8 feet Multipack

12 feet Shelf-6 + 8 feet Shelf-7 + 4 feet Multipack

So the stores are assigned a template according to their total size and shelf planning. These stores are named as 'grouped stores' .

### Future Ideas on Pepsi Side
